title: Serious question
author: Pokemasteringo
text: Hi guys, I have a serious question involving getting involved into the field of anthropology, I am very interested in learning more about the field and would love to be part of an apprenticeship or study directly under a professional anthropologist, how doable is this? Are there any opportunities to do so? Would anyone be interested in guiding me? I know I will probably get a lot of answers about going to college and getting a degree but honestly I don’t want to go back to college, I have a true passion for the field seriously, since I was a little kid I used to read encyclopedias my grandparents had for fun, even now as an adult I continuously desire to learn what is that truly makes us human and how we can utilize this knowledge to develop the world; thank you for your time and I wish to hear from you all. Blessings.

title: Race as folk taxonomy
author: artofneed51
text:
I would enjoy making the case to my family that race is not scientifically proveable and that what we argue about mainly concerns culturally accepted norms.

Can you help me construct a better argument? I know the concept of race can not be proven via empirical evidence, skin pigmentation has more to do with exposure to UV rays and the differences between groups of people are attributable to cultural traditions.

How else is this proveable?

text: However, one of skeletons – found at the very top of the House of the Thirteen Heavens – gave the archaeologists more food for thought. Based on various marks on its bones, they first deemed it a man: a hunter or warrior. But the latest DNA analysis revealed that she was a woman. More surprisingly, the analysis showed that the body was much older than the structures themselves. While the temple was built in 540 CE, the woman's skeleton dates to 400 BCE, nearly a millennium earlier. "These people had carried the body with them wherever they went, and they were carrying it for at least 950 years," Quiroz said.
